text: all right hello everyone my name is martin siegmund and i'm a freelance open source developer contributing to uno
platform which is what i'm about to talk to you today about so
um platform is a cross-platform application development solution and to
ease into the topic so to speak i will start by describing
if the presentation is going to work yeah i will start by describing what cross-platform application development
really is and what it means so when you want to target as many devices as you want
you need to target all the major platforms that are available so you would start with windows to target
desktops you then target android to target android phones and tablets
you can also target ios to target their mobile devices and also mac os
and finally to target all users on the world wide web you would target the the
desktop browsers and mobile browsers of course to do that you would have to
have four different teams of developers each proficient in their own specific language for business logic as well as
for the ui logic so for example on windows we have c sharp and xaml as the ui logic
then you have android kotlin java and axml and on ios we have swift and swift
ui and finally on the browser we have to use html and css and javascript
so it's very hard to actually get these four different teams together and have
them work on four different applications even though they are exactly the same they have four different code bases they
have four different uh you have to develop each feature for different times you have to fix all bugs four times so
it's very inefficient very costly and uh it's just not something you want to do
so of course as we are developers and lazy creatures we decided to improve upon that by sharing some
code so in our case as dotnet developers we would like to share the business logic in c sharp so as you can see we
improved the situation by sharing business logic in c-sharp and having native ui on each platform so for
example uh we can write windows applications using c-sharp and xaml on android we write
c-sharp code using xamarin android and then have axml as ui layer and so on
for the web we have we are using blazer in this case so we can share c sharp logic with the other applications but
the the presentation layer is still javascript and html css
so that's a remarkable improvement already but it's not enough because we still have different ui languages and we need
to have designers and proficient developers for each of those platforms
so let's improve even further by bringing in xamarin forms and maui
xamarin forms and maui is the solution brought by microsoft is a cross-platform framework using xaml and c-sharp
and it allows you to write single code based applications that target all mobile platforms that's android ios and
windows the problem here is that the xml ui language that's there is not the classic
example you know from windows so it's not the wpf or silverlight like xaml
it's a simplified structure that doesn't allow you for styling and templating
also it has some different conventions so for example if you know uh from
some example you have with in xamarin forms you have with request and you have to work with it a little bit differently
so there's a lot of differences that you have to learn if your windows developer coming to the zombie informs and also as
you can see the same xaml code is rendered differently on each device so
on ios it looks like an ios application on android like an android application on windows like windows application
which may be what you want but not necessarily if you want to introduce
some company branding into your application so in that case you would have to
modify the code to actually display differently on each device but to bring in the same design so that's that's a
lot of additional work that you would have to do and that's problematic maui is solving this very much because
they're bringing more styling capabilities and native rendering but that's still not released officially
so that's the situation we're in right now and in addition
we have just lost one of the major platforms of course xamarin forms doesn't allow you to target the web so
in this case if you want to target the browsers you cannot actually do that with xamarin forms and you will have to
go with blazer or some other solution to actually bring a web application
to the table so let's go now to uno platform which promises to fix all that and bring
single code based applications that can target all devices and and platforms so
in this case you would be able to target windows android ios mac os
linux and also web via web assembly so all these platforms with just single
code base compile and run everywhere and the promise of win of uno platform
is that it's compatible with vin ui or uw's windows platform so you just write
windows applications you work with them like windows applications and they run everywhere
so that's a very nice thing to have and of course uh it's a big promise and i think that uno platform delivers on that
and i will show it and prove it to you so how does this all work uh i will show

android and linux and for all those platforms on the same level as vin ui
you can see there is uno platform and uno platform provides the exact same api
surface as vinui so you can take your application code and compile it against
uno platform instead of windows and the the trick that uno platform is using
is that their namespaces are exactly the same as vinui namespaces
so if you have windows microsoft ui example controls button on windows you
have the same namespace the same class on uno platform and has all the same properties all the same events and
everything exactly the same as on windows so you can take the same code and just
compile it against a different provider of those functionalities
and for the ui it's actually taking a similar step the similar approach as maui is going to
take where the ui is rendered using native ui rendering capabilities of each

different ways how you can scale the application so you can decide to have it run
in in interpreted mode which is the smallest one but it's the least performant
so in that case you are trading performance for size then you can have mixed mode which is
partly interpreted and partly native which is much faster but a little bit
bigger and finally you can have full native mode where the application is quite large but once you load it one
time in the browser it will be cached forever and you can then use it without
downloading it again so so you have to decide what's the best scenario for your specific usage
yeah definitely it's still larger than normally normal html application because there's a lot of libraries that have to
